title: Configure authentication services (LDAP
content:
You can configure LDAP/SAML/OAuth authentication services in IdM Admin portal. When users log in to the tenant, the users are authenticated by the corresponding authentication service:

  • For SAML and OAuth, the user first needs to enter the user name in the suite login page, and then the system redirects the user to the external IdP login page where the user is asked for the username again along with the password. If you configure the default login type of the tenant to SAML or OAuth, the system redirects to the external IdP without asking for the username first.
  • For LDAP and Database, the user first needs to enter the user name, click Next, and then enter the password on the login page of the tenant. If you configure the default login type of the tenant to LDAP or DB, the system displays the username and password fields together without asking for the username first with the Next button.
  • Don't create configurations for other authentication types such as CERTIFICATE because they're currently not supported.
  • If you add both the SAML and OAuth authentications and you don't set the default login type in IdM, the system will authenticate users only with the OAuth authentication. If the OAuth authentication fails, the system won't try the SAML authentication.
  • When configuring the authentication group type in IdM, don't select API Default for SAML and OAuth.

Add LDAP authentication

To add the LDAP authentication, create a configuration for LDAP, and then create a configuration group for the LDAP configuration.

Create an LDAP configuration

To create an LDAP configuration, follow these steps:

  1. In Suite Administration, click the IdM settings tab on the tenant detail page. The system opens the Authentication page for the corresponding organization in the IdM Admin Portal of the suite. 
  2. From the CONFIGURATIONS section, click to add one authentication.
  3. Select LDAP as the authentication type from the drop-down list, and then click CREATE.

  4. Enter the related LDAP configuration settings as described in the following table:

    LDAP Server Settings

    Setting Required Description OpenLDAP example value
    Display Name Yes Name of the LDAP configuration. This name cannot be changed when you reconfigure the settings.
    Shared in same family No Share the configurations within the same family.
    Hostname Yes Fully-qualified domain name or IP address of the LDAP server.

    Note: If the SSL Connection checkbox is selected, use FQDN instead of IP address as the hostname and make sure that the specified FQDN is the same as the value defined for Common Name (CN) in the certificate that you use.

    		 server.domain.com
    Port Yes Port of the LDAP server. LDAP servers typically use port 389 or secure port 636. 389
    SSL Connection No

    If you want to enable SSL connection, select SSL Connection, and then upload the LDAP SSL certificate.

    Tip: This parameter represents the Enable SSL field when you previously configure the LDAP authentication in Suite Administration in former releases.
    Certificate No

    LDAP SSL certificate. 

    • The supported certificate format is: .pem (Base-64 Encoded)
    • By default, IdM uses a one-layer certificate for the SSL connection. IdM uses the first layer certificate by default when a multiple-level certificate has been provided. However, as long as any of the certificates in the multiple-level ca chain works, IdM functions well.

    • If the certificate is signed by a multiple-level ca, the CA cert file should be concatenated by following the order below:

      -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
<ldap server certificate >
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
<intermediate-level ca >
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
<root ca>
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
    • There is no empty line between the certificates
    		 
    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIIErjCCA5agAwIBAgIQBYAmfwbylVM0jhwYWl7uLjANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQsFADBh
MQswCQYDVQQGEwJVUzEVMBMGA1UEChMMRGlnaUNlcnQgSW5jMRkwFwYDVQQLExB3
…………..
UQ9Qqtb1GX91AJ7i4153TikGgYCdwYkBURD8gSVe8OAco6IfZOYt/TEwii1Ivi1C
qnuUlWpsF1LdQNIdfbW3TSe0BhQa7ifbVIfvPWHYOu3rkg1ZeMo6XRU9B4n5VyJY
RmE=
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
    Validate Certificate No Verify the LDAP SSL certificate you provided.
    Base DN No The Distinguished Name (DN) of the LDAP entity from which you want to start your user search. dc=Service Management Automation,dc=com
    User ID (Full DN) No The Distinguished Name (DN) of a user with search privileges on the LDAP directory server.


    Example: CN=Administrator,CN=Users,DC=example,DC=com

    		 cn=admin,dc=Service Management Automation,dc=com
    Password No Password of the specified user ID.

    LDAP Attribute

    Setting Required Description OpenLDAP example value
    Full Name No Full name to be included in the user search. This full name will be mapped to IdM user's full name. cn
    User Email Yes Property that contains the user's email address (specific to the selected LDAP vendor, for example, MS Active Directory). This user email will be mapped to IdM user's email. mail
    Manager Identifier No Any attribute (for example DN or CN) of the user who is the user's manager. This manager identifier will be mapped to IdM user's manager identifier. manager
    Manager Identifier Value No The value of the identifier. For example, if you specified the DN in the Manager Identifier field, enter dn. dn
    User Avatar No Attribute for the user avatar image. You must specify an LDAP record property name that exists on the LDAP server.
    Priority No Specifies the priority of the domain controller. The priority determines the order in which clients contact a domain controller.
    Referral Search No Select to follow LDAP referrals to another server that offers the requested information.

    User Login Settings

    Setting Required Description OpenLDAP example value
    Username Attribute Yes

    The name of the attribute of a user object, which is a unique field to identify a user. This field doesn't represent the user name entered by the user when logging in. The value for this field can be determined by looking at one or more user objects in the LDAP directory to determine which attribute consistently contains a unique user name.
    This attribute is for IdM authentication.

    Tip: This parameter represents the User principal name field when you previously configure the LDAP authentication in Suite Administration in former releases.

    		 uid
    User Search Base No Parameters to indicate which attributes are to be included in the user search. OU=idmtest,DC=adfshp,DC=com
    User Search Filter Yes LDAP pattern to use when searching for a user account. Example: (AccountName={0}) The user search filter must include the pattern {0}, which is replaced with the user name entered on login. For example, (&(AccountName={0})(objectClass=user)).
    Search Subtree No Select to search the subtree below the base DN (including the base DN level).

    Group Settings

    Setting Required Description OpenLDAP example value
    Group Name Attribute No Specify from which group to do the future search.
    Group Object Classes Yes

    Specify the group object class list. Each object in an LDAP directory has at least one object class associated with it. The object class determines the characteristics of this object, in particular, the set of attributes that the object can have. Use a comma to separate the group object classes.

    • If the Group Search Base starts with cn, enter "group" here
    • If the Group Search Base starts with ou, enter "groupOfNames,groupOfUniqueNames,group" here

    Tip: This parameter represents the Group DN type field when you previously configure the LDAP authentication in Suite Administration in former releases. If you previously selected Group in Suite Administration, you can enter "group" here; if you previously selected Organization Unit, you can enter "groupOfNames,groupOfUniqueNames,group" here.

    		 groupOfNames,group
    Group Search Base Yes Parameters to indicate which attributes are to be included in the group search.

    Tip: This parameter represents the Group DN field when you previously configure the LDAP authentication in Suite Administration in former releases.

    		 ou=Groups,dc=example,dc=net
    Group Search Filter No LDAP pattern to use when searching for a group list and search for which group the user belongs to. (&(cn=TS-SA-*)(objectClass=group))
    Group Membership No Specify the attribute of the group that will be used to search its members. member, uniqueMember
    Load Group as Attribute No Load group as users' attribute when this checkbox is selected.

    Mapping Attributes

    Setting Required Description LDAP value Field in Suite Administration
    First Name Yes

    First name of the user.

    		 givenName First name
    Family Name Yes Family name of the user. sn Last name
    Middle Name No Middle name of the user. middleName Middle name
    Office Phone Number No Office phone number of the user. telephoneNumber Office home number
    Home Phone Number No Home phone number of the user. homePhone Home phone number
    Mobile Phone Number No Mobile phone number of the user. mobile Mobile phone number
    Zip Code No Zip code of the user. postalCode Zip code
    Language No Language of the user. preferredLanguage Language
    Customer UID No

    Unique ID.

    		 employeeNumber Customer UID
    Location No Location of the user.
    Set up the attribute values according to the above table because of the IdM design. Otherwise, you cannot sync them to BO. The attribute values are apllicable to both OpenLDAP and Active Directory.
  5. Click SAVE.

Create a configuration group for LDAP 

To create a configuration group for LDAP, follow these steps:

  1. After you create an LDAP configuration, from the CONFIGURATION GROUPS section, click to add an authentication group.

  2. In the Name field, enter ldap.

  3. In the Display Name field, enter a display name for the authentication group. 
  4. In Authentication Group Type, select the authentication group type (or types).
    If you select WEB Default, IdM will use this authentication group by default when a user logs in through the UI. Changing the authentication method for UI logins using this option won't sync with Suite Administration. To effect this change, use the default login type field on the tenant's General tab within Suite Administration.
    If you select API Default, IdM will use this authentication group by default when a user logs in using back-end APIs.
    If you select both WEB Default and API Default, make sure the authentication services you use for UI and API logins are the same. Or, some integrations such as Native SACM and the integration between Integration Studio and Operations and Orchestration won't work.

  5. In the Configurations field, select the LDAP authentication configuration that you just created. If needed, you can add multiple LDAP authentication configurations to the LDAP configuration group.

  6. Click SAVE.

Add SAML authentication

To configure SAML authentication for Service Management, you must complete configurations in both the IdP (ADFS, Azure AD, and Okta) and Suite Administration.

Prerequisites

Here are the assumptions and prerequisites before you start to set up the SAML authentication:

  • You have created an account with a tenant associated.
  • You have a working SAML 2.0 compliant Identity Provider (IdP).
  • You are familiar with configuring and managing your organization's IdP.
  • Your IdP's system clock is synchronized with a reliable time source. If it's not, the tokens generated will be unusable and SSO will fail.

Download metadata from the suite

Use the following URL to download the idm_saml_metadata.xml file from IdM. You will need this file later.

  • For system-level SAML configuration: https://<suite FQDN or custom domain>/idm-service/saml/metadata
  • For tenant-level SAML configuration: https://<suite FQDN or custom domain>/idm-service/saml/metadata/<tenantID>

Configure SAML SSO in the IdP

This section describes how to configure SAML-based SSO in your IdP: ADFS, Azure AD, and Okta.

Required outgoing claim types or claims

For the SAML SSO configuration to work, you must configure a specific set of outgoing claim types (for ADFS) or claims (for Azure AD) during the SAML configuration in the IdP. These outgoing claim types or claims correspond to user attributes that must be propagated from the IdP to Service Management.

The following table lists the required outgoing claim types or claim names and the corresponding user attributes in Service Management. Note that custom SAML attribute mapping is not supported.

Outgoing claim type / Claim name User attribute in Service Management* Description
Name ID User Principal Name

This is the username used to log in to Service Management. It corresponds to the Login name field in Suite Administration.

After you have mapped an IdP attribute to the Name ID outgoing claim type or claim, don't change the mapped IdP attribute. Otherwise, multiple users will be created for the same person in Service Management.

 Values of the IdP attribute mapped to Name ID must be unique because Login name must be unique.
firstName First name

The first name of the user. 
middleName Middle name The middle name of the user.
familyName Last name

The last name of the user.
fullName N/A

This corresponds to the Full Name field in Suite Administration.

In Service Management, the Name field stores the "full name" of the user, but its value doesn't come from the fullName claim defined in the IdP—it's the concatenation of the firstName and familyName (if the default workflow is used󠅑).
officePhoneNumber Office phone number The office phone number of the user.
homePhoneNumber Home phone number The home phone number of the user.
mobilePhoneNumber Mobile phone number The mobile phone number of the user.
language Language

The tenant login language of the user. The tenant UI is initially displayed in this language after the user logs in to the tenant. 

The system supports a pre-defined list of locales:

  • en: English
  • ar: Arabic
  • zh-CN: Simplified Chinese
  • nl: Dutch
  • fr: French
  • de: German
  • it: Italian
  • ja: Japanese
  • ko: Korean
  • pl: Polish
  • pt-BR: Portuguese (Brazil)
  • ru: Russian
  • es: Spanish
  • tr: Turkish
  • el: Greek
  • da: Danish
  • nb: Norwegian
  • en-GB: English (UK)
  • sv: Swedish
  • he: Hebrew
  • pt-PT: Portuguese (Portugal)
location Location The location of the user.
zipCode Zip code The zip code of the user.
email Email The email address of the user.

* Unless otherwise noted, user attributes in this column exist in both Service Management and Suite Administration, with the same name.

If using ADFS as the IdP

Perform the following steps to add a Relying Party Trust in ADFS:

  1. On AD Server, from Server Manager > tools, open AD FS Management.
  2. Right-click on Trust Relationships, and then click Add Relying Party Trust.
  3. Select Import data about the relying party from a file.
  4. Select the idm_saml_metadata.xml file that you downloaded previously.
  5. Click Next.
  6. If the wizard prompts a message indicating that some content of metadata isn't supported, just click OK. You can safely ignore this warning.
  7. Specify a display name for the IdM service, and add optional notes. Then, click Next.
  8. Make sure that you select the I don't want to configure multi-factor authentication setting for this relying party trust at this time option, and then click Next.
  9. Select the Permit all users to access this relying party issuance authorization rule, and then click Next.
  10. In the Ready to Add Trust step, check that the Endpoints tab contains multiple endpoint values. If not, verify that your metadata was generated with https protocol.
  11. Leave the Open the Edit Claim Rules dialog checkbox selected, and then click Close to close the wizard.
  12. The Add Transform Claim Rule Wizard is displayed.
  13. From the Add Transform Claim Rule Wizard, under the Issuance transform rules tab, select Add Rule, select Send LDAP Attributes as Claims, and then click Next.
  14. Edit the rule.
      The LDAP attributes in the following screenshot are just examples. Use the actual LDAP attributes in your system based on your business requirements.

    Configure the outgoing claim types according to the attribute mapping table at the beginning of this section.

If using Azure AD as the IdP

Perform the following steps to configure SAML-based SSO in Azure.

  • You must have an Azure AD user account with the required permission to configure SSO in Azure (for example, Application Administrator, Cloud Application Administrator, or Global Administrator).
  • You can only configure one Azure AD for each tenant.

1. Add an enterprise application

To add an enterprise application to your Azure AD tenant:

  1. Go to the Azure Active Directory Admin Center and sign in with your Azure AD user account.
  2. In the left menu, click Enterprise applications. The All applications pane opens.
  3. Click New application.
  4. Click Create your own application on the resulting page.
  5. In the "Create your own application" pane, enter a name for the application, select Integrate any other application you don't find in the gallery (Non-gallery), and then click Add.

2. Assign users to the application

To enable Azure AD users to access Service Management through SAML-based SSO, you must assign users to the application you added above.

The following describes how to assign users to the application via Azure AD Admin Center. You can also assign users to the application using other methods. See Assigning users to application.

  1. In the Azure AD Admin Center, click Enterprise applications, and then search for and select the application to which you want to assign users.
  2. In the left pane, click Users and groups, and then click Add user/group.
  3. In the Add Assignment pane, click None Selected under Users and groups.
  4. In the Users and groups pane, search for and select the users or groups that you want to assign to the application, and then click Select.
  5. In the Add Assignment pane, click Assign.

3. Configure SAML SSO for the application

To configure SAML SSO, complete the following steps:

  1. In the Azure AD Admin Center, click Enterprise applications, and then search for and select the application for which you want to configure SSO.
  2. In the application's Overview pane, click 2. Set up single sign on.
  3. Click SAML under Select a single sign on method.
  4. Click Upload metadata file, select the IdM SAML metadata file downloaded before, and then click Open.
  5. In the Basic SAML Configuration pane, click Save. The configurations should resemble the following:

  6. Click Edit in the Attributes & Claims pane to edit and add claims. 

    The application must have a specific set of claims. See the table at the beginning of this section for the required claim names. Map each claim to an appropriate Azure AD attribute according to your business needs.

    • Edit the default claims. For each claim, clear the value of the Namespace field, and update the name of the claim to the required value.

      You don't need to update the name of the Name ID claim, which is read-only.

    • Add new claims according to the table at the beginning of this section. Leave the Namespace field empty.

    The configurations should resemble the following:

  7. In the SAML Signing Certificate pane, download files that will be required for SAML SSO configuration in IdM. The files to download depend on the method you select to retrieve metadata in the IdM SSO configuration form.

    • If you use the IDP Metadata method, click Download next to Federation Metadata XML to download the metadata file.

      The IDP Metadata method is recommended because it is faster and safer than the other method.

    • If you use the IDP Metadata URL method, click Download next to Certificate (Base64) to download the certificate file. Also take note of the App Federation Metadata Url value, which is needed when configuring SSO in IdM.

If using Okta as the IdP

Perform the following steps to configure SAML-based SSO in Okta.

1. Add an enterprise application

To add an enterprise application to your Okta instance:

  1. In the Admin Console, go to Applications > Applications.
  2. Click Create App Integration.
  3. Select SAML 2.0 as the Sign-on method.
  4. Click Next.
  5. Enter a name in the App name field (for example,  "Service Management Dev Tenant").
  6. To import data from the downloaded metadata file to Okta, open the Service Management IdM metadata file in a text editor, and then copy and paste the data into the Okta wizard.
    While most fields in the SAML settings can remain as their default values, certain fields require manual configuration. Ensure you make the following adjustments.
    General section
    Fields in SAML settings Description Value
    Single sign-on URL

    The location to send the SAML assertion using a POST operation. This URL is required and serves as the default Assertion Consumer Services (ACS) URL value for the Service Provider (SP). This URL is always used for Identity Provider (IdP) initiated sign-on requests.

    Use this for Recipient URL and Destination URL is selected by default. This setting uses the same URL for both the recipient and destination URLs. If your integration requires different URLs, clear the checkbox and provide values for the following fields:

    • Recipient URL: The location where the application can present the SAML assertion. This is usually the Single Sign-On (SSO) URL.
    • Destination URL: The location to send the SAML Response, as defined in the SAML assertion.
    		 Use the value of the AssertionConsumerService Location property from the Service Management IdM metadata.

    This value should resemble: https://<Service Management hostname>/idm-service/saml/SSO
    Audience URI (SP Entity ID)

    The intended audience of the SAML assertion. This is usually the Entity ID of your application.

    Use the value of EntityDescriptor entityID property from the Service Management IdM metadata.

    This value should resemble: https://<Service Management hostname>/idm-service/saml/metadata
    Default Relay State

    The URL of the resource to direct users after they successfully sign in to the SP using SAML.

    		 Leave it blank.
    Advanced Settings section
    Fields in SAML settings Description Value
    Signature Certificate The file that contains the public key certificate (in PEM format) used to validate the SAML sign-in request and the Single Logout (SLO) request.

    Create a new text file with name like XXX.okta_saml.crt, and create certificate header and footer lines like this:
                -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
                
                -----END CERTIFICATE-----
    Then paste in between the headers the certificate value from the Service Management metadata file, property X509Certificate. Save the file.

    Now select that certificate file in the Okta Signature Certificate field.
    Enable Single Logout Allows users to sign out of both a configured custom app and Okta with a single click (but not out of other apps that are open). Enable Single Logout by clicking Allow application to initiate Single Logout.
    Single Logout URL Specify where to send the sign-out response.
    This field appears when Enable Single Logout is selected.

    Use the value of SingleLogoutService Binding property from the Service Management IdM metadata.

    This value should resemble: https://<Service Management hostname>/idm-service/saml/SingleLogout
    SP Issuer The issuer ID for the service provider.

    This field appears when Enable Single Logout is selected.

    		 Leave it blank.
    Signed Requests Select this to validate all SAML requests using the Signature Certificate. The payload from the SAML request is validated, and Okta dynamically reads any single sign-on (SSO) URLs from the request.

    This checkbox appears after you upload a Signature Certificate.

    		 Leave it blank.
    Attribute Statements Define custom attribute statements for the integration. These statements are inserted into the SAML assertions shared with your app.

    Configure the following fields:

    • Email field: enter user.email
    • firstName field: enter user.firstName
    • familyName field: enter user.lastName
    • Name ID field: enter user.login
  7. Click Next and Finish in the Okta wizard.

The following screenshots display the details of SAML setting configurations.


2. Assign users to the application

In the new Okta application integration, use the Assignments tab to assign users access rights to Service Management.

3. Download the Okta metadata
Follow these steps to download the required Okta metadata file for configuring SAML SSO in IdM:

  1. Click the Sign On tab of the new Okta Service Management application integration.
  2. In the Metadata URL section, click the Copy button to duplicate the URL.
  3. Paste the URL into your web browser to access and retrieve the Okta metadata.
  4. Right-click on the displayed text, and then click Save as to save it as a .xml file. 

4. Configure the application as a Bookmark App

If you want to access Service Management from an Okta dashboard tile, follow the steps to configure the application integration to use "Service Provider" initiated login. By default, the Service Management application tile in Okta will launch as an "Identity Provider" initiated login which Service Management doesn't currently support and will cause a "This site can't be reached" error. To fix this issue, you must configure the application as a Bookmark App. 

Step 1: Remove the visibility of the original tile for Service Management.

Step 2: Create a Bookmark App as a visible tile, and configure it to launch Service Management using the SSO URL (from the Service Management metadata and used in the initial configuration).

For details, see Simulate an IdP-initiated flow with the Bookmark App from the Okta's support document.

Create a SAML configuration in IdM

IdM supports both the system-level SAML setting and the tenant-level SAML setting.

To set up SAML authentication, follow these steps:

  1. In Suite Administration, click the IdM settings tab on the tenant details page. The system opens the Authentication page for the corresponding organization in the IdM Admin Portal. 
  2. From the CONFIGURATIONS section, click   to add one authentication, and then choose SAML as the authentication type.
  3. Select the authentication group to which you want to add this authentication configuration, and then click CREATE.
  4. Enter a name for the SAML server. This name can't include the following special characters (or any blank spaces): @, ;, :, =, &, <, >, #, {, }, |, `, ^, ~, %, ', ?, ", \, /, [, and ].
  5. Enter the display name for the SAML server.
  6. For the SP Metadata Option field, choose to enable either the system-level SAML setting or the tennant-level SAML setting. The default setting is Global.
  7. Do one of the following:
    • Select IDP Metadata URL, enter the following IdP metadata URL, and then upload the certificate of the IdP.
      • ADFS: https://<ad_host>/FederationMetadata/2007-06/FederationMetadata.xml
      • Azure AD: The App Federation Metadata URL you noted during SAML configuration in Azure
    • Select IDP Metadata, and then upload the IdP metadata file.
      • ADFS: You can download the metadata file from this URL: https://<ad_host>/FederationMetadata/2007-06/FederationMetadata.xml
      • Azure AD: The Federation Metadata XML you downloaded during SAML configuration in Azure
  8. Click SAVE.

The system-level SAML configurations are complete. To configure tenant-level SAML setting, continue with the following steps:

Click Customization and select the SAML tab to customize the SAML authentication.

  • Entity Base URL: The URL serving as the basis for the record ID in the SAML metadata. If you leave this setting empty, IdM generates and caches the record ID based on values in the first server request. 
  • First Binding: The name of SAML's first binding. The expected value is post or artifact. The default value is artifact.
  • Second Binding: The name of SAML's second binding. The expected value is post or artifact. The default value is post.
  • Third Binding: The name of SAML's third binding. The expected value is post, paos, or artifact.
  • IDP Initiated Default URL: The default return URL initiated by the IdP.
  • IDP Initiated Launchpad URL: The default launchpad URL initiated by the IdP.
  • SAML Logout Enabled: Select this option if you want IdM to return users to the IdP login page after they log out. It is enabled by default.
  • Back IdM On Logout: Select this option if you want IdM to send users to the IdM logout page instead of the login page after they log out. It is enabled by default.
  • Request Force Authentication: Select this option if you want IdM to send SAML requests with the ForceAuthN option. It means that IdP must perform fresh authentication again for each login even when the request from IdM comes with IdP Primary Refresh Token (PRT)/cookie.
  • Request Signed: Select this option if you want IdM to generate a signature for the SAML request, so that the SAML IdP can validate the integrity of the SAML request based on the signature. It is enabled by default.
  • Want Assertion Signed: Select this option if you want the SAML response to include a signature generated at the IdP, so that IdM can validate the integrity of the SAML response. It is enabled by default.

Create a SAML configuration group in IdM

To create a configuration group for SAML, follow these steps:

  1. After you create a SAML configuration, from the CONFIGURATION GROUPS section, click to add an authentication group.

  2. In the Name field, enter saml.

  3. In the Display Name field, enter a display name for the authentication group. 
  4. In Authentication Group Type, select the authentication group type (or types).
    If you select WEB Default, IdM will use this authentication group by default when a user logs in through the UI. Changing the authentication method for UI logins using this option won't sync with Suite Administration. To effect this change, use the default login type field on the tenant's General tab within Suite Administration.
    Don't select the API Default option.

  5. In the Configurations field, select the SAML authentication configuration that you just created. You can add only one SAML authentication configuration to the SAML configuration group.

  6. Click SAVE.

Now, you have completed the SAML configurations. SAML users can access the tenant. After the user logs in to the tenant for the first time, the system automatically synchronizes their user profiles to Suite Administration.

Verify the SAML SSO configuration

To verify that the SAML SSO configuration works, check the following:

  • Users added in the IdP can log in to Service Management using their IdP user credentials.
  • After such a user logs in to Service Management, you can see the user record for the user created in Suite Administration, and various user-related fields that correspond to the outgoing claim types or claims you added in the IdP have the IdP value populated.

Add OAuth authentication

OAuth is an open protocol to allow secure authorization. Setting up the OAuth authentication enables the suite to verify the identity of users and access users' private resources in the identity provider such as  OpenID Connect. Users don't need to share their credentials. 

OAuth users can access the tenant after the configurations are completed. The user profile is synced to Suite Administration after the user logs in to the tenant for the first time.

OAuth user can't be used for the following integration use cases:

  • Publishing Operations Orchestration (OO) flows from OO Designer to OO Central
  • Service Management and Design and Deploy (DND) integration
  • DND and OO integration via DND integration user

Before adding an OAuth authentication, add your company's proxy settings to the deployment:

  1. Log in to a control plane node or a bastion node as root or a sudo user, and run the following command to update the IdM deployment :
    kubectl edit deployment idm -n <suite namespace> 
  2. Press i and add the following to the env section:
    - name: HTTPS_PROXY
      value: <proxy>
    - name: HTTP_PROXY
      value: <proxy>
  3. Press :wq to save the file and quit. Wait until the idm pod is running. You can run the following command to check the idm pod status:
    kubectl get pods -n <suite namespace> | grep idm

To add the OAuth authentication, create a configuration for OAuth, and then create a configuration group for the OAuth configuration.

Create an OAuth configuration

To create an OAuth configuration, follow these steps:

  1. In Suite Administration, click the IdM settings tab in the tenant detail page. The system opens the Authentication page for the corresponding organization in the IdM Admin Portal of the suite. 
  2. From the CONFIGURATIONS section, click to add one authentication.
  3. Select OAUTH as the authentication type from the drop-down list, and then click CREATE.

  4. Enter the related OAuth configuration settings. You can get the information from your OpenID identity provider.

    Field Required Description
    Display Name Yes The display name of this configuration.
    Shared in same family No Share the authentication settings within the same family.  The supported values are "false" and "true''.
    Client ID Yes The value of Client ID that you get from the OpenID identity provider.
    Client Sercet Yes The value of Client Secret that you get from the OpenID identity provider.
    HTTP Method Yes The HTTP method of getting a user's information from the endpoint. The supported values are "GET" and "POST".
    : By selecting The GET option, you are disabling or bypassing security features, thereby exposing the system to increased security risks. By using this option, you understand and agree to assume all associated risks and hold OpenText harmless for the same.
    IDP URL Yes The endpoint or URL path provided by the OpenID Identity Provider. The URL set for "Redirect URL" will be directed to the IDP URL.
    Redirect URL Yes The value of redirect URL of the IDP URL for login.
    Scope Yes The value of scope. For example, "openid email".
    State Supported No Whether support the State Supported feature. The supported values are "false" and "true''.
    Username Attribute Yes The attribute to define a username.
    User Info Endpoint No An OAuth 2.0 Protected Resource that returns Claims about the authenticated end user. For example, /userinfo.
    Token Endpoint Yes The token endpoint of the OpenID identity provider. The Token Endpoint is used to obtain a Token Response. For example, /token.
    Authentication Endpoint Yes The Authorization Endpoint performs authentication of an end user. This is done by sending the user agent to the authorization server's endpoint for authentication and authorization, using request parameters defined by OAuth 2.0 and additional parameters and parameter values defined by OpenID Connect. For example, /authorize.
    Logout Endpoint No The token endpoint where you can end a session.
    Additional Parameter No The additional parameter for authentication.
  5. Click SAVE.

Create a configuration group for OAuth

To create a configuration group for OAuth, follow these steps:

  1. After you create an OAuth configuration, from the CONFIGURATION GROUPS section, click to add an authentication group.

  2. In the Name field, enter oauth.

  3. In the Display Name field, enter a display name for the authentication group. 
  4. In Authentication Group Type, select the authentication group type (or types).
    If you select WEB Default, IdM will use this authentication group by default when a user logs in through the UI. Changing the authentication method for UI logins using this option won't sync with Suite Administration. To effect this change, use the default login type field on the tenant's General tab within Suite Administration.
    Don't select the API Default option.

  5. In the Configurations field, select the OAuth authentication configuration that you just created. You can add only one OAuth authentication configuration to the OAuth configuration group.

  6. Click SAVE.

Example: configure OAuth authentication with Google accounts

To enable OAuth-based Google Sign-In on a Service Management tenant:

  1. Use your Google account to log in to Google API Console.
  2. Fill out the OAuth consent screen, add required information like a product name and support email address.
  3. Click + CREATE CREDENTIALS, select OAuth client ID. 
  4. Select Web application as the Application type and specify a name for your OAuth 2.0 client.
  5. Add https://<Service Management FQDN>/idm-service/idm/v0/oauth2 as an Authorized redirect URI, click CREATE. Note the Client ID and Client Secret after the OAuth client is created, both values are needed when you create an OAuth configuration in Suite Administration. You can also get these values from Google API Console.
  6. Log in to Suite Administration, go to Tenants, and select the tenant that you want to enable OAuth-based Google Sign-In.
  7. Click the IdM settings tab in the tenant detail page, from the CONFIGURATIONS section, click to add one authentication.
  8. Select OAUTH as the authentication type, and then click CREATE.

  9. Enter the following OAuth configuration settings. 

    Field Description
    Display Name The display name of this configuration.
    Client ID The value of Client ID that you get from step 5 above.
    Client Secret The value of Client Secret that you get from step 5 above.
    IDP URL https://accounts.google.com
    Scope openid profile email
    User Info Endpoint https://openidconnect.googleapis.com/v1/userinfo
    Token Endpoint https://oauth2.googleapis.com/token
    Authorization Endpoint https://accounts.google.com/o/oauth2/v2/auth
    Logout Endpoint https://accounts.google.com/Logout
     
    Additional Parameter The additional parameter for authentication.
  10. Click SAVE.
